articles.headline: Raising Rates Too Soon: The Mistake Central Banks Keep Making
articles.snippet: Can looking at central bankers’ blunders from the recent past offer any useful guidance for what the Fed ought to do this week? It’s worth hoping.
articles.abstract: Can looking at central bankers’ blunders from the recent past offer any useful guidance for what the Fed ought to do this week? It’s worth hoping.
articles.lead_paragraph: Central banks, to boil their job down to its simplest level, face this perpetual dilemma: Should they push for easier money, to try to support a nation’s economic growth, or for tighter money, to try to head off inflation?

articles.headline: Tough Going for Health Co-ops
articles.snippet: The federal marketplace was intended to increase competition, partly by creating consumer-led co-ops. But many new entrants have struggled, and several have folded.
articles.abstract: The federal marketplace was intended to increase competition, partly by creating consumer-led co-ops. But many new entrants have struggled, and several have folded.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late last month, the Nevada Health Co-op became the third casualty among 23 insurance start-ups created under the federal health care law to inject competition for coverage in certain parts of the country.

articles.headline: Coming Soon to Facebook: A ‘Dislike’ Button
articles.snippet: The social network’s thumbs-up button will soon be accompanied by a way to express more negative emotions.
articles.abstract: The social network’s thumbs-up button will soon be accompanied by a way to express more negative emotions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook’s famous “like” button, with its silhouette of an upturned thumb, will soon be accompanied by an alternative: a way to “dislike” a post.

articles.headline: A Migration Juggernaut Is Headed for Europe
articles.snippet: Europe can expect several decades of heavy immigration, and the sooner it develops policies to help integrate migrants the better for all concerned.
articles.abstract: Europe can expect several decades of heavy immigration, and the sooner it develops policies to help integrate migrants the better for all concerned.
articles.lead_paragraph: European leaders probably don’t want to hear this now, as they frantically try to close their borders to stop hundreds of thousands of desperate migrants and asylum seekers escaping hunger and violence in Africa and the Middle East. But they are dealing with the unstoppable force of demography.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Discord Over Ex-Im Bank Intensifies, as G.E. Shifts Jobs Abroad
articles.snippet: General Electric and Boeing blamed a halt in export credit for job transfers and a loss of contracts, reigniting Republican infighting over the fate of the Ex-Im Bank.
articles.abstract: General Electric and Boeing blamed a halt in export credit for job transfers and a loss of contracts, reigniting Republican infighting over the fate of the Ex-Im Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — General Electric announced plans on Tuesday to move 500 jobs overseas, and Boeing said it had lost a second foreign satellite contract in weeks, developments that both corporate giants blamed on the Republican-led Congress’s failure to keep the federal Export-Import Bank open to help finance new deals.

articles.headline: More Republicans See Donald Trump as a Winner, Poll Finds
articles.snippet: A Times/CBS News poll finds that, although many Republicans have reservations about Mr. Trump, he appears to be gaining acceptance.
articles.abstract: A Times/CBS News poll finds that, although many Republicans have reservations about Mr. Trump, he appears to be gaining acceptance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans increasingly think that Donald J. Trump has the best chance of winning the 2016 presidential election as their nominee as confidence fades in traditional politicians like Jeb Bush and Scott Walker, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Analysts Detail Claims That Reports on ISIS Were Distorted
articles.snippet: The Pentagon’s inspector general is examining claims that senior military officers manipulated conclusions about progress against the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon’s inspector general is examining claims that senior military officers manipulated conclusions about progress against the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of intelligence analysts have provided investigators with documents they say show that senior military officers manipulated the conclusions of reports on the war against the Islamic State, according to several government officials, as lawmakers from both parties voiced growing anger that they may have received a distorted picture about the military campaign’s progress.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Attitudes Shift on Paid Leave: Dads Sue, Too
articles.snippet: As more men take time off work when a baby is born, many are also filing lawsuits and complaints about how much time they can take and the professional setbacks they endure when they return to work.
articles.abstract: As more men take time off work when a baby is born, many are also filing lawsuits and complaints about how much time they can take and the professional setbacks they endure when they return to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, women who believed their employers had punished them with lower wages and missed promotions after they had become mothers have been filing gender discrimination complaints and bringing lawsuits.

articles.headline: Obama Weighing Talks With Putin on Syrian Crisis
articles.snippet: President Obama’s administration is debating whether the two leaders should try to work out their differences. Some fear a meeting would only play into Mr. Putin’s hands.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s administration is debating whether the two leaders should try to work out their differences. Some fear a meeting would only play into Mr. Putin’s hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, President Obama has resisted meeting one on one with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and only reluctantly taken a phone call, freezing out the Kremlin leader over his intervention in Ukraine in their own personal cold war.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Approaches SABMiller on Possible Takeover
articles.snippet: The deal would combine the world’s two largest brewers of beer, bringing some of the most popular brands under one roof.
articles.abstract: The deal would combine the world’s two largest brewers of beer, bringing some of the most popular brands under one roof.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time when investors are nervous and antitrust regulators are suspicious, the prospect of a $100 billion-plus merger on the horizon may seem remote.
articles.byline: By Chad Bray and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Handcuffed for Making Clock, Ahmed Mohamed, 14, Wins Time With Obama
articles.snippet: President Obama praised an Irving high school freshman’s interest in science after his arrest raised questions of bias toward a Muslim student who happens to love tinkering.
articles.abstract: President Obama praised an Irving high school freshman’s interest in science after his arrest raised questions of bias toward a Muslim student who happens to love tinkering.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ahmed Mohamed’s homemade alarm clock got him suspended from his suburban Dallas high school and detained and handcuffed by police officers on Monday after school officials accused him of making a fake bomb. By Wednesday, it had brought him an invitation to the White House, support from Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mark Zuckerberg, and a moment of head-spinning attention as questions arose whether he had been targeted because of his name and his religion.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: Udacity Says It Can Teach Tech Skills to Millions, and Fast
articles.snippet: The online teaching start-up’s “nanodegree” program lets students take their time, offers personalized grading and rewards those who finish.
articles.abstract: The online teaching start-up’s “nanodegree” program lets students take their time, offers personalized grading and rewards those who finish.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I’m the least experienced person on my engineering team at Google,” Kelly Marchisio, a 25-year-old computer programmer, told me recently. “I frankly might be one of the least experienced engineers at Google, period.”

articles.headline: Silent on Priorities, Yellen Makes Fed Choice a Cliffhanger
articles.snippet: Economists and others are pushing the Fed to keep rates near zero, citing a slow economic recovery, while some Fed officials are saying the labor market is strong enough.
articles.abstract: Economists and others are pushing the Fed to keep rates near zero, citing a slow economic recovery, while some Fed officials are saying the labor market is strong enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, faces a crucial moment on Thursday when the Fed’s policy-making committee announces whether the time has come to start raising interest rates.
